CF6E0839A4464A618137F22D95970D65.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

EA52721C7344486CB67D965E2E70B597.description: explain that science and technology are developed to meet societal needs and expand human capability

E5CCD07B4366446AA747FA2E23B48900.description: explain that decisions regarding the application of scientific and technological development involve a variety of perspectives, including social, cultural, environmental, ethical and economic considerations

2B7F47461F0C4D30B44485C1FE7E5969.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

AE0268182FB440E1A86406BAFE2BD9D3.description: describe the energy transformations involved in converting tidal energy to electrical energy and compare tidal power to hydroelectric power; e.g., tidal generating stations at the Bay of Fundy, Canada and La Rance, France.

16944AC8CC7A4D4995A8186041F35BA3.description: explain the source of tides, in terms of gravitational attraction and the relative motions of the sun, moon and Earth

EAFD7540E0664C648348E651F8CEF723.description: contrast, quantitatively, the orders of magnitude of energy produced by nuclear, chemical and phase changes

C2696C6A216744CF8A05BBDF64B0D138.description: compare and contrast conventional coal, oil-fired or hydroelectric power stations with nuclear power stations, in terms of purpose, process of energy conversions, design and function

D782FDB4BEE54E49B0859A921EF50F2C.description: trace the relationship between nuclear energy and geothermal energy

A578588A4C9F49E796A81E363A8D1A6D.description: describe, in general terms, the operation of a fission reactor (e.g., the Canadian Deuterium Uranium [CANDU] Reactor) and the current state of fusion research

04184522FFA7443DBF8B6033A87658C9.description: describe mass-energy changes in fission and fusion reactions, as represented by the formula E = mc2

12C671E4BA58458BA014BCBF9B56BFB8.description: describe the main types and sources of radioactive decay and resulting ionizing radiation; i.e., alpha (α), beta (β) and gamma (γ) decay

DCCD44CE7AA743048CC11804288383E7.description: explain the difference between fission and fusion and balance simple nuclear reaction equations to show the conservation of nucleons; e.g.,10n+23592U=14156Ba+9236Kr+ 310n; 21H+21H=32He+10n

6CF1B2C165A54ACE8C12CD7FEF31EECD.description: describe the functioning of renewable energy technologies and assess their advantages and disadvantages, including active and passive solar-heating technologies, wind turbines, hydroelectric power, biomass energy, geothermal energy, hydrogen fuel cells

5EB96B511EB34455B8ED524CCCB856D4.description: describe the conversion of solar energy into renewable forms (e.g., wind, hydropower, chemical potential energy by photosynthesis) and nonrenewable forms (e.g., coal, oil and gas) and further conversion into electrical and thermal energy

53DB3DA5622E47BCB1B6EE2CBC3C04D3.description: contrast the proportion of solar energy that creates wind and drives the water cycle with the small proportion captured by photosynthesis as chemical potential energy

D81D1E8EE49A40E289E843D25789FCE5.description: explain how Hess's Law, ΔH∘=∑ΔfH∘ (products)- ∑ΔfH∘ (reactants), leads to prediction of heats of combustion

B27AAA5A97AA4A57BC20BD048F2C2940.description: Students will describe the sun as Earth's main source of energy and explain the functioning of some conventional and alternative technologies that convert solar, nuclear, tidal and other energy sources into useable forms.

4D27DE4874214E77B01E268D957E4214.description: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

2469057AD3194B99A5B2AD2E9EF39BA9.description: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

775E059CB93D4307A7AF0D1DB627F4BB.description: conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information

5C688118C3A247A4B1C14F1A58D07C8E.description: formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues

212D4059741A436885F5D4E3FE3DBB69.description: explain that science and technology are developed to meet societal needs and expand human capability

B111280379144015B409D4E25DF0BB6C.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

A9CC74BB332B4CE5A8CEC963D1DB26D9.description: describe how the Aboriginal perspective of an interconnected environment demonstrates the need to balance resource extraction with environmental impact.

623E584418174762AAB94A742D2CD72C.description: describe the environmental impact of developing and using various energy sources; i.e., conventional oil, oil sands, solar power, wind power, biomass, hydroelectricity, coalburning power, nuclear power, geothermal

64254A7420D04B2AA4B197CA3412362B.description: explain the need to develop technologies that use renewable and nonrenewable energy sources to meet the increasing global demand

4684ED8B02E0429186BFAF72D90E0B94.description: apply the concept of sustainable development to increasing the efficient use of energy; e.g., efficient use of energy in the home, in industry and in transportation

5AD7CED11B864585A3DBCCE80030F873.description: compare Canada's per-capita energy consumption with developed and developing countries and identify factors that affect consumption; e.g., economy, lifestyle, level of technology, geography, climate

ACBE2380FD2A459D8AFC400BC22311EC.description: compare the energy consumption of contemporary society with that of traditional cultures and precontact Aboriginal societies, and investigate and analyze the exponential growth of global energy consumption in recent history

78E5F83B9B13484883F8532DC54FAC8F.description: Students will explain the need for balancing the growth in global energy demands with maintaining a viable biosphere.

24208054BD024B5E8D85B04E5FBB4225.description: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

2674EBA6BDFC4F2BB92176D228A8F364.description: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

509FD54BAD4D43F7A085013807A34820.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Science and Technology Emphasis)

C0392106A943427EAB9E3DA67A0C0D0A.description: explain how the appropriateness, risks and benefits of technologies need to be assessed for each potential application from a variety of perspectives, including sustainability

FC3726F90C72491BA1779090262C86AC.description: explain that scientific knowledge may lead to the development of new technologies, and new technologies may lead to or facilitate scientific discovery

16D833E01A6D4309B467B5783C0DB409.description: explain that the goal of technology is to provide solutions to practical problems

D65BD0E1957D47C2B8171AC7720DACE2.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

E6683D9373B942EB9E461E36112E079E.description: describe, in general terms, the evolution of stars and the existence of black holes, white dwarves and neutron stars.

B0BD162E0A4F4D6CB7F605199577F619.description: describe technologies used to study stars

798E3C214AE949FD8D4782E2A181308E.description: describe, in general terms, how a spectroscope can be used to determine the composition of incandescent objects or substances, and the conditions necessary to produce emission (bright line) and absorption (dark line) spectra, in terms of light source and temperature

0E433CDB50744E2CA87CBF6D70803038.description: explain that nuclear fusion in the sun, represented by the equation 21H+21H = 32He+10n produces a wide spectrum of EMR

B706B4D62CCD4E1E8340E5C837BD0FEC.description: explain, in general terms, the design of telescopes that are used to gather information about the universe through the collection of as much EMR as possible; i.e., reflecting and refracting optical and radio telescopes

95BB9ECBB21942B1BB05B5D372DD2F45.description: investigate and describe the relationships of the variables in the universal wave equation v=fλ

9F21D8C53C5743E78FB83487B2075626.description: compare and contrast the properties of radiation, from any region of the electromagnetic spectrum, with those of visible light; i.e., wavelength, frequency, speed, reflection, refraction, diffraction, penetrability

6DD543F0054F450A865F81A546020DD3.description: investigate and describe, qualitatively, the phenomena of reflection, refraction, diffraction and polarization of visible light

D8498BD729184D7387B06ECDE13FF211.description: recognize that Earth's atmosphere absorbs certain frequencies of EMR

B6592FE62A0B4A6D99A18F799D2506DC.description: compare and contrast, to each other, the various constituents of the electromagnetic spectrum, on the basis of source, frequency, wavelength and energy, and their effect on living tissue; e.g., UV radiation on human skin and photosynthetic organisms; gamma radiation on living cells; visible light on plants, phytoplankton and humans; artificial illumination on the growth of plants

6CD3A1A36F7F4E15930695542A373A69.description: describe the range of the electromagnetic spectrum from long, low-frequency radio waves through microwaves, infrared (IR) rays, visible light rays and ultraviolet (UV) radiation to very short, high-frequency waves, such as X-rays and gamma rays

CD4A9822F5F5456DBB4E649EE51C0CCB.description: Students will describe the properties of the electromagnetic spectrum and their applications in medical technologies, communication systems and remote-sensing technologies used to study the universe.

452FE506995543F4B325323A72683673.description: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

C0DC78589D7A4469AB7DF6C270087980.description: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

733D3F18F86B42DDA1F4D7B88F916E77.description: explain that technological development may involve the creation of prototypes, the testing of prototypes and the application of knowledge from related and interdisciplinary fields

8E4B4E47A5844D3385993B5710EA0CA0.description: explain that the goal of technologies, based on the application of field theory, is to provide solutions to practical problems

5E69BFCCF40E4ED0B8CA57906C0D97F9.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

A0B746451DB34EF5B0658BD7BD7D2849.description: describe, in terms of design and electrical energy, the functioning of safety technologies; e.g., circuit fuses and breakers, polarized plugs and ground wiring.

D47066B68DCB4D16B8E840CB63D94EF7.description: compare the general design and function of a DC electric motor and a generator

0562063DE6E0466B9FBD02D2BDD0095B.description: describe the advantage of AC over DC for transmitting and using electrical energy

F0B2D4AF4A9B41729DA950C98CD67AB3.description: describe the operation of a transformer, in terms of the relationship among current, voltage and the number of turns in the primary and secondary coils, using the equation Np / Ns = Vp / Vs = Is / Ip

92C9C84E840B46D285EF58B4B89E29FA.description: distinguish between alternating current (AC) and direct current (DC) in terms of electron flow and electric field

FD5BF4E88B844CEEB49FD6FDDD683755.description: describe electrical energy in kilowatt hours and joules, using the equation Ee = Pt for electrical energy and the equation P = VI for power

50D0CFBD17484FCA8DCD12CD36C45CE7.description: describe the relationships, for up to three resistors, among power, current, voltage and resistance for series and parallel circuits, using the equations V = IR, P = VI, P=I2R, RT = R1 + R2 + R3, and 1/Rt=1/R1+1/R2+1/R3

76426B7E48D44BEAB399534BDAA7E837.description: describe the effect of a conductor moving through a magnetic field and inducing an electrical current

5BDF647D051B4516BDEEE96080A3E57F.description: describe gravitational and electric field strength at a given distance from a mass or a point charge, using the equations |g̅|=Gm/r2 and |E̅|=kq/r2

63900EB6BF7844BC875B8458BFFFF718.description: compare the basic properties (source, direction and strength) of vector fields (gravitational, electric and magnetic), as determined by a test object

E21F89347DF34A408119757C7E6093BA.description: compare the interaction between static electric charges with the interaction between magnetic poles and with the interaction between two masses at a distance

B845A8C27DE04FC1A0969D6ABE81CDC1.description: define a field as a property of space around a mass, an electric charge or a magnet that causes another mass, electric charge or magnet introduced in to this region to experience a force

3494D434E6304176A1031CF130ED3D4A.description: Students will explain field theory and analyze its applications in technologies used to produce, transmit and transform electrical energy.

95DA2C2F93814C19BD0679889E967C8F.description: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

CBA6280A2F18489B81E8BDFB274BB841.description: describe alternatives to the use of chemical technologies; e.g., bioremediation for contaminated soil, biological controls for pests, biodegradable products.

F5F985F010D74FACBD1273A0E8C867CC.description: describe technologies used to reduce the production and emission of chemical compounds that have the potential to harm the environment; e.g., activities related to internal combustion engines, smelting, pesticide production, sweetening of sour gas

4BC0D31918D64539926E0DBB7E4FB634.description: describe the risks and benefits of using chemical processes that may produce products and/or by-products that have the potential to harm the environment

D46B7C3A106F431C896CA82DF53CC903.description: Students will analyze, from a variety of perspectives, the risks and benefits of using chemical processes in meeting human needs and assess technologies for reducing the impact of chemical compounds on the environment.

FDCC57DB0F194B0BB9395D762F315544.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

57370A3493E043F1AA328BA225C526EE.description: explain the mechanism and significance of biomagnification.

1BADA7C49CB64E37862D4EB396E0F72F.description: identify and explain how human activities and natural events contribute to the production of photochemical smog, the depletion of the ozone layer and increased concentrations of organic compounds in the environment; e.g., driving a car, use of CFCs, agricultural practices

74AB28613F2B46F280538EB353CB9496.description: list the sources of, and analyze the hazards posed by, halogenated hydrocarbons and benzene derivatives

97F3EA4643D54C4099026F64EDEBB296.description: identify organic compounds commonly considered to be environmental pollutants; i.e., hydrocarbons, organic waste, CFCs, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), dioxins and furans

E2CD5800C1214FB08B58CE7CF39EC261.description: identify and name carbon compounds, using International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature that contain up to three carbon atoms in the parent chain and a single occurrence of one type of functional group, including simple halogenated hydrocarbons hydrocarbons (e.g., 2-chloropropane), alcohols (e.g., propan-1-ol), carboxylic acids (e.g., propanoic acid) and esters (e.g., methyl propanoate)

3EC6D9E7B1FD47F490A2BA6CE1233D04.description: Students will analyze the sources of organic compounds and their effects on the environment.

E40480E2A1BB4D4A8436C3E0144B3DE8.description: demonstrate an understanding that science and technology developed to meet societal needs and expand human capacity

D6D5AD21BE0F4437BF3F4E31DAC5C27A.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

29F9CC5C027B47DCA66B2629C3E6EB98.description: describe impacts on the biotic and abiotic components of the environment caused by acid deposition; e.g., lowered pH in water systems, accelerated corrosion, metal leaching from bedrock, the impact of leached metals on plants and the food chain.

299FD9F6F116417EBBF3CF4CC2BEA904.description: outline the chemical reactions (e.g., combustion reactions) that produce air pollutants (i.e., sulfur dioxide and nitrous oxides) that, when combined with water, ultimately result in acid deposition

B3E85DA24496470AA7C06783179DD238.description: explain what is meant by buffering capacity; e.g., soil or bedrock

EC906ABB8D114126B5A6DE58675F1861.description: trace the historical use of acid-base indicators; e.g., early Aboriginal methods of using extracts from natural substances

6773784D72EB4D88A59856939B0F5C26.description: explain the importance of maintaining a relatively constant pH in a living system; e.g., the role of the hydrogen carbonate ion in maintaining the pH of blood, the evolution of the Arctic herb Artemisia tilesii in resisting acidic moisture by extracting calcium from the soil and pumping the calcium to its leaves

662D057F5E9045A19089A35C580BA110.description: explain, qualitatively, how buffers maintain a relatively constant pH when a small amount of acid or base is added to an aqueous system

933C81E851C2416FAE01EE79EB701552.description: describe the relationship between pH and hydronium ion concentration

3EC071E198B942C8B7845C777E2BF2C9.description: differentiate among acids, bases, neutral ionic compounds, neutral molecular compounds and strong and weak acids, based on appropriate diagnostic tests

B041FB1E780548E4B067097349C81F55.description: define acids and bases in terms of proton donors and proton acceptors

C6DF850FBDE44B4E923D95D25EAE93E7.description: Students will analyze the sources of acids and bases and their effects on the environment.

1A4DD472906943819D74504210015571.description: explain that science and technology are developed to meet societal needs and expand human capability

73383C2CE8DF4A0C9B5E4F0FDA76E450.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

E0425D6B331D407BBBDD741F6DEE206E.description: describe the development of resistance in bacteria and viruses, based on the concepts of mutation, plasmid transfer, transformation and natural selection.

E5C72E798253486CAA3AB07E950CCD24.description: describe, in general terms, genetic engineering and its application to gene therapy and the development of genetically modified organisms

A8E632FAA8C04D38B7E62B1AA692B9C3.description: describe how mutations in DNA affect the proteins produced resulting in human diseases; e.g., sickle-cell anemia, hemophilia, Huntington's disease, cystic fibrosis

895EFDA8A7E044E9875975DD26D3AD4E.description: describe the role of proteins in the human body as regulatory molecules (enzymes), as structural molecules and as a source of energy

12002AD8CA7940D3AE183AAFE8414EEA.description: describe a primary function of DNA by describing how an amino acid sequence of a polypeptide (protein) is determined by the sequence of DNA triplet codes, i.e., use of a table of DNA triplets matched with amino acids

423328C5C21147BBB9A5D69385C65ACB.description: explain the general process of DNA replication

225B36A907AA4E15BF9C9030D0347A5A.description: describe the structure of DNA by: identifying the structure of DNA as a double helix, listing the essential components of DNA as nucleotides and identifying the base pairings between the strands of the double helix

4C662C7871C4407E864521D2E5B86A7B.description: distinguish autosomal from sex-linked patterns of inheritance

A31A8C31A4A14678AD973146643003F4.description: explain, with the aid of Punnett squares, the inheritance of single traits by applying current understanding of the gene, segregation and dominance

49EBAEFD5B994623A88B1BC0BD4F49A5.description: describe, in general, the behaviour of chromosomes during mitosis, meiosis and fertilization

B5387E5017074BB1A7A818894AA637A6.description: Students will apply the principles of heredity and molecular genetics to explain how human diseases can arise from inherited traits, the risks and benefits of genetic technology, and the need for ethical considerations in the application of scientific knowledge.

426C9B7751FC4DACA89BBBE94A729D87.description: describe how society provides direction for scientific and technological development

E23DBEBBF3C1483891152B8CB4CEC8BD.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

C7A3219F9E734D859CA08FAED6D4FE38.description: analyze how vaccines defend against disease-causing bacteria and viruses.

496BF353CACA43CA8420EC9B60A94683.description: explain the interrelationship of autoimmune diseases and the human immune system; e.g., multiple sclerosis, arthritis, lupus

BAF0F76ED65F48A2A84C40E0E46808F1.description: describe, in general terms, how immunity to pathogens develops, how the immune system responds to a foreign antigen and the roles of macrophages, B cells, helper T cells, killer T cells, suppressor T cells, memory cells and antibodies

9A1984A2B00E4596832877469245BAE9.description: describe, in general terms, the function of various body mechanisms, including the skin and body secretions (i.e., tears and stomach acid), in preventing pathogens from entering body tissues

9CAD75690B1A4CD8B330A013E91B5F10.description: describe how pathogens in the environment (e.g., mosquito-borne parasites, bacteria, viruses) enter the circulatory system and may have an adverse affect on health

C2CCB0EFC8974C2E97977183ECC46EE4.description: Students will analyze the defense mechanisms used by the human body to protect itself from pathogens found in the external environment.

FDCCA09E64FC4B76AA1C2697F07ADEA5.description: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

6D8DAC86B1FC40DFB2524D8DA5F82A7C.description: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

62BA0115C9C946D387A3E3B7AF1720F6.description: describe how society provides direction for scientific and technological development

9C32255B366F4968B8A66FFAC8F19A87.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

5F0DF5A17F9543768E0AEB12BC494730.description: describe the main components of blood (i.e., plasma, red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, blood proteins that include antibodies, hemoglobin and hormones) and their role in the transportation of substances (e.g., nutrients, wastes, gases, hormones), blood clotting, the defence against pathogens and the distribution of thermal energy.

CD66A09AE8D34A679592A7D7E8D510F3.description: describe the structure and function of blood vessels and the flow of blood through arteries, arterioles, venules, veins and capillaries

E13851E44C7642A693BDD3F0F224E7A8.description: describe the rhythmic contraction of the heart and its function in the general circulation of blood through pulmonary and systemic pathways

85237D41F36E4A2F8785C81E0121A10A.description: describe the principal structures and associated blood vessels of the heart; i.e., ventricles, atria, septum, valves (specific names of valves not required), aorta, vena cavae, pulmonary arteries and veins, coronary arteries

88FE9A0693AA46BB9C374E1324BF8169.description: Students will analyze how the human circulatory system facilitates interaction between blood cells and the external environment and investigate cardiovascular health.

3AA0B701A6D345BD921D1ABE8FD6ACFF.description: Living Systems Respond to Their Environment
